articles.headline: The Ink Fades on a Profession as India Modernizes
articles.snippet: Cellphones made the services of the professional letter writer obsolete, but G. P. Sawant isn’t complaining.
articles.abstract: Cellphones made the services of the professional letter writer obsolete, but G. P. Sawant isn’t complaining.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  G. P. Sawant never charged the prostitutes for his letter-writing services.

articles.headline: Holiday Spending Is Weak, as Retailers Expected
articles.snippet: Uneasy about the economy and unimpressed by merchandise, American shoppers delivered the bleak holiday shopping season retailers had expected. Spending rose just 3.6 percent over 2006.
articles.abstract: Uneasy about the economy and unimpressed by merchandise, American shoppers delivered the bleak holiday shopping season retailers had expected. Spending rose just 3.6 percent over 2006.
articles.lead_paragraph: American consumers, uneasy about the economy and unimpressed by the merchandise in stores, delivered the bleak holiday shopping season retailers had expected, if not feared, according to one early but influential projection.

articles.headline: Both Sides Cite Science to Address Altered Corn
articles.snippet: A proposal to ban the planting of a genetically modified corn strain  sets up a bitter war within the European Union.
articles.abstract: A proposal to ban the planting of a genetically modified corn strain  sets up a bitter war within the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS  A proposal that Europe’s top environment official made last month, to ban the planting of a genetically modified corn strain, sets up a bitter war within the European Union, where politicians have done their best to dance around the issue.

articles.headline: Rapidly, Buffett Secures a Deal for $4.5 Billion
articles.snippet: Warren E. Buffett’s deal for a conglomerate suggests that he is finally finding acquisitions he can get excited about.
articles.abstract: Warren E. Buffett’s deal for a conglomerate suggests that he is finally finding acquisitions he can get excited about.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett may be a choosy shopper, but when he sees a firm he likes, he moves fast.

articles.headline: The Résumé Factor: Those 2 Terms as First Lady
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton seemed to learn more as first lady through osmosis than through decision-making.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton seemed to learn more as first lady through osmosis than through decision-making.
articles.lead_paragraph: As first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton jaw-boned the authoritarian president of Uzbekistan to leave his car and shake hands with people. She argued with the Czech prime minister about democracy. She cajoled Roman Catholic and Protestant women to talk to one another in Northern Ireland. She traveled to 79 countries in total, little of it leisure; one meeting with mutilated Rwandan refugees so unsettled her that she threw up afterward.

articles.headline: At 60% of Total, Texas is Bucking Execution Trend
articles.snippet: With enthusiasm for executions falling elsewhere, 25 of the 42 executions in the U.S. last year were in Texas.
articles.abstract: With enthusiasm for executions falling elsewhere, 25 of the 42 executions in the U.S. last year were in Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year’s death penalty bombshells  a de facto national moratorium, a state abolition and the smallest number of executions in more than a decade  have masked what may be the most significant and lasting development. For the first time in the modern history of the death penalty, more than 60 percent of all American executions took place in Texas.

articles.headline: Masterful Web Entrepreneurs Hit a Snag in Miami’s Condo Market
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley stars Jim Clark and Tom Jermoluk are finding it a lot harder to maneuver through the real estate market than to master the Internet.
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley stars Jim Clark and Tom Jermoluk are finding it a lot harder to maneuver through the real estate market than to master the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jim Clark and Tom Jermoluk cut a swath through Silicon Valley in the 1990s with companies like Silicon Graphics, Netscape and WebMD. But they are finding that it is a lot harder to maneuver through the real estate market than to master the Internet.

articles.headline: Let’s Raise a Glass to Fairness
articles.snippet: Globalization and low taxes have created a golden age of inexpensive wine and liquor, but cheap booze comes at a heavy societal cost.
articles.abstract: Globalization and low taxes have created a golden age of inexpensive wine and liquor, but cheap booze comes at a heavy societal cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We are fortunate to be living in a time when there is a lot of good wine from around the world,” Philip Cook was telling me the other day.

articles.headline: Hospitals Look to Nuclear Tool  to Fight Cancer
articles.snippet: A push by medical centers to turn nuclear particle accelerators into weapons against cancer reflects the best and worst of America’s health system, experts say.
articles.abstract: A push by medical centers to turn nuclear particle accelerators into weapons against cancer reflects the best and worst of America’s health system, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a new nuclear arms race under way  in hospitals.
